title: How you can use impostor syndrome to your benefit - Mike Cannon-Brookes

multiple-choice.question: What is impostor syndrome?

options.text: A feeling of being well out of one's depth, yet already entrenched in a situation.

options.label: B
options.text: A fear of failure and being unable to do something.

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why do people fear the wrong things? - Gerd Gigerenzer

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between absolute risk and relative risk?

options.label: A
options.text: Absolute risk is expressed as a percentage, while relative risk is expressed as a ratio.

options.label: B
options.text: Absolute risk is expressed as a ratio, while relative risk is expressed as a percentage.

options.label: C
options.text: Absolute risk is the likelihood of an event occurring, while relative risk is the change in risk.

options.label: D
options.text: Absolute risk is the change in risk, while relative risk is the likelihood of an event occurring.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main advantage of expressing risk in absolute terms?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the risk sound more significant.

options.label: B
options.text: It takes into account the actual number of people affected.

options.label: D
options.text: It is more commonly used in medical research.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a choice that reduces one risk but increases another risk?

options.label: A
options.text: Taking a medication that reduces heart attack risk.

options.label: B
options.text: Avoiding a swim to avoid a shark attack.

options.label: C
options.text: Quitting smoking to reduce the risk of lung cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: Taking a medication that reduces the risk of cancer.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of expressing risk in relative terms?

options.label: A
options.text: It does not take into account the actual number of people affected.

options.label: B
options.text: It is more difficult to understand.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not commonly used in medical research.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not relevant to individual circumstances.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a personal circumstance that may influence risk evaluation?
What is the main message of the text regarding risk evaluation?

options.label: A
options.text: Risk evaluation is a simple process.

options.label: B
options.text: Risk evaluation is a complex and nuanced process.

options.label: C
options.text: Risk evaluation is not relevant to individual circumstances.

options.label: D
options.text: Risk evaluation is only relevant to medical research.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a treatment or intervention that may be overestimated due to relative risk?

options.label: B
options.text: Medication that reduces heart attack risk.

options.label: D
options.text: Surgery to treat a particular condition.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a 40% reduction in heart attack risk and a 0.6% absolute risk reduction?

options.label: B
options.text: The 0.6% absolute risk reduction is more relevant to individual circumstances.

options.label: C
options.text: The 40% reduction is more commonly used in medical research.

options.label: D
options.text: The 0.6% absolute risk reduction is more difficult to understand.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a choice that may be influenced by personal preference?

options.label: A
options.text: Taking a medication that reduces heart attack risk.

options.label: B
options.text: Avoiding a swim to avoid a shark attack.

options.label: C
options.text: Quitting smoking to reduce the risk of lung cancer.

options.label: D
options.text: Taking a medication that reduces the risk of cancer.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main conclusion of the text regarding risk evaluation?

options.label: A
options.text: Risk evaluation is a simple process.

options.label: B
options.text: Risk evaluation is a complex and nuanced process that requires careful consideration of multiple factors.

options.label: C
options.text: Risk evaluation is only relevant to medical research.

options.label: D
options.text: Risk evaluation is not relevant to individual circumstances.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Check if the stack is in a random order.

options.label: D
options.text: Check if the stack is a certain height.

options.label: C
options.text: The stack will remain in its current state.

options.label: A
options.text: To store information about the blocks.

options.label: B
options.text: To check if a block is a palindrome.

options.label: C
options.text: To count the number of blocks.

options.label: D
options.text: To determine the height of the stack.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The stack can be made into a palindrome.

options.label: C
options.text: The stack will remain in its current state.

options.text: It is more complex than the naïve solution.

options.label: D
options.text: It is less accurate than the naïve solution.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome if Hedge takes too long to find a good stack?

options.label: A
options.text: Ethic and Hedge will be safe.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker thinks that punishment is the only solution.

options.text: The speaker wants their father to change and apologize.

options.label: C
